results.adx_keywords: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships;Defense of Marriage Act (1996);Supreme Court;Decisions and Verdicts;California;Windsor, Edith Schlain;Spyer, Thea Clara;Scalia, Antonin;Kennedy, Anthony M
results.title: Supreme Court Bolsters Gay Marriage With Two Major Rulings
results.abstract: The court ruled unconstitutional a 1996 law denying federal benefits to legally married same-sex couples and effectively permitted gay marriage in California.
des_facet: SAME-SEX MARRIAGE, CIVIL UNIONS AND DOMESTIC PARTNERSHIPS

media.caption: Plaintiffs and lawyers in Hollingsworth v. Perry, the California Proposition 8 case, Wednesday on steps of the Supreme Court.
People celebrated outside the Supreme Court on Wednesday after it struck down the Defense of Marriage Act.
Two of the plaintiffs in the Proposition 8 case, Jeffrey Zarrillo, center foreground, and Paul Katami, center right, with one of their lawyers, David Boies, far right, outside the Supreme Court.
Sandra Stier, center left, and Kristin Perry, center right, plaintiffs in the California case, spoke to reporters after the decisions by the Supreme Court were announced in Washington on Wednesday.
Wendy Kennedy, left, embraced her spouse, Deborah Spell, at the Stonewall Inn in New York after the Supreme Court struck down the Defense of Marriage Act.
A couple celebrated at City Hall in San Francisco on Wednesday after hearing that the Supreme Court had struck down the Defense of Marriage Act.

results.adx_keywords: Food Network;Deen, Paula;Discrimination;Suits and Litigation (Civil);Today (TV Program);Race and Ethnicity
results.title: Food Network Drops Paula Deen
results.abstract: The network announced Friday that it would not renew Ms. Deen’s contract at the end of June, after she apologized for using racist language.

media.caption: Paula Deen cooking on the “Today” show earlier this year.
Paula Deen issued an apology on a YouTube video on Friday.

results.adx_keywords: Supreme Court;Voting Rights Act (1965);Voter Registration and Requirements;Discrimination;Southern States (US);Ginsburg, Ruth Bader;Roberts, John G Jr;Decisions and Verdicts;States (US);United States;Elections;Blacks
results.title: Supreme Court Invalidates Key Part of Voting Rights Act
results.abstract: The Supreme Court split along ideological lines with its ruling that Congress had not provided adequate justification for subjecting the states, mostly in the South, to federal oversight.

media.caption: Wade Henderson, president and C.E.O. of the Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights, criticized the decision on Tuesday.
Representative John Lewis of Georgia, center left, and Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, right, at a news conference. The Voting Rights Act covered nine states, mostly in the South.
media.copyright: Drew Angerer for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Football;New England Patriots;Hernandez, Aaron;Murders and Attempted Murders;Lloyd, Odin;Attleboro (Mass)
results.title: Former Patriots Tight End Is Charged With Murder
results.abstract: The N.F.L. player Aaron Hernandez was charged on Wednesday with the murder of Odin Lloyd, a 27-year-old semipro football player who was found dead on June 17.

media.caption: Hernandez was taken into custody at his home, less than a mile from where a 27-year-old man was found dead.
media.copyright: George Rizer for The Boston Globe, via Getty Images

media.caption: Aaron Hernandez helped lead the Patriots to the Super Bowl two seasons ago.
media.copyright: Timothy A. Clary/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

media.caption: The tight end in Attleboro District Court with one of his lawyers, Michael K. Fee, right.
Family members of Odin Lloyd, a semipro football player who was found shot to death less than a mile from Hernandez’s home.
media.copyright: Pool photo by Mike George/Sun Chronicle

results.adx_keywords: Snowden, Edward J;Classified Information and State Secrets;Surveillance of Citizens by Government;United States International Relations;Fugitives;National Security Agency;Russia;China;Hong Kong;Ecuador
results.byline: By PETER BAKER and ELLEN BARRY
results.title: Leaker’s Flight Raises Tension Between U.S. and 3 Nations
results.abstract: The Obama administration escalated its criticism on Monday of Russia, China and Ecuador, the countries that appeared to be protecting Edward J. Snowden, who is wanted on spying charges.

media.caption: With Edward J. Snowden apparently in hiding in Moscow, journalists gathered Monday at the Ecuadorean Embassy there.
media.copyright: James Hill for The New York Times

media.caption: Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, said, “We do not buy the suggestion that China could not have taken action.”
The passenger plane, flight SU 150 to Havana, from Moscow Sheremetyevo airport, on Monday before it took off without Edward J. Snowden.

results.adx_keywords: Abortion;Washington (State)
results.title: My Abortion, at 23 Weeks
results.abstract: Second-trimester abortions must remain legal because critical information about fetal health is often not available before then.

results.adx_keywords: Snowden, Edward J;National Security Agency;Hong Kong;Surveillance of Citizens by Government;United States International Relations;Russia;Ecuador;Classified Information and State Secrets
results.byline: By PETER BAKER and ELLEN BARRY
results.title: Snowden, in Russia, Seeks Asylum in Ecuador
results.abstract: Edward J. Snowden arrived in Moscow on Sunday as American officials pressed Russia to turn him over and warned countries in Latin America not to harbor him or allow him passage.

media.caption: On Sunday, a crowd of journalists greeted a passenger on the same Hong Kong flight Edward J. Snowden took to Moscow.
media.copyright: James Hill for The New York Times

media.caption: The car of Ecuador’s ambassador at the Moscow airport. Ecuador confirmed getting an asylum request from Mr. Snowden.

results.adx_keywords: Colleges and Universities;Humanities;Reading and Writing Skills (Education)
results.title: The Decline and Fall of the English Major
results.abstract: In the drift away from the humanities, we risk losing something essential in ourselves.

results.adx_keywords: Deen, Paula;Food Network;Discrimination;Blacks
results.title: Paula’s Worst Ingredients
results.abstract: The exiled empress of the Food Network had her lucrative recipe down pat, but didn’t put enough self-awareness in the mix.

media.caption: Frank Bruni

results.adx_keywords: Exercise
results.title: The Rise of the Minimalist Workout
results.abstract: People have long been trying to figure out what the right amount of exercise is, but the focus lately is on the shortest period possible.

results.adx_keywords: Amsterdam (Netherlands);Bicycles and Bicycling;Parking
results.title: The Dutch Prize Their Pedal Power, but a Sea of Bikes Swamps Their Capital
results.abstract: Bicycles, the preferred means of travel, are clogging streets and overwhelming parking spaces in Amsterdam, causing some to say the unthinkable: There are too many bikes.

media.caption: Amsterdam has more bicycles than people, and although it has thousands of bike racks, demand for them still outstrips supply.
media.copyright: Pavel Prokopchik for The New York Times

media.caption: Bicycles clog streets and cause traffic jams, but as one official put it, “You cannot imagine if all this traffic were cars.”
media.copyright: Pavel Prokopchik for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Snowden, Edward J;Russia;China;United States International Relations;National Security Agency;Classified Information and State Secrets;Surveillance of Citizens by Government;Fugitives;Putin, Vladimir V;Lavrov, Sergey V
results.byline: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN, ELLEN BARRY and PETER BAKER
results.title: With Snowden in Middle, U.S. and Russia Joust, and Cool Off
results.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Tuesday appeared to rule out sending Edward J. Snowden back to the United States, as Moscow and Washington tried to prevent a cold-war-style standoff.

media.caption: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Finland on Tuesday. He said Edward J. Snowden could go where he wanted.
President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at a ceremony in Turku, Finland, on Tuesday.

results.adx_keywords: Supreme Court;Affirmative Action;Decisions and Verdicts;University of Texas at Austin;Ginsburg, Ruth Bader;Kennedy, Anthony M;Colleges and Universities;Race and Ethnicity;Fisher, Abigail Noel;Admissions Standards
results.title: Justices Step Up Scrutiny of Race in College Entry
results.abstract: The 7-to-1 ruling was both modest and significant, and its recalibration of how courts review the programs is likely to give rise to a wave of challenges to college admissions decisions.

media.caption: Abigail Fisher, who was denied admission to the University of Texas at Austin, said her race was held against her.
media.copyright: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times

media.caption: The scene at the Supreme Court before the decision came down. The ruling is likely to set off new challenges to affirmative action.

results.adx_keywords: Law and Legislation;Women's Rights;Abortion;Filibusters and Debate Curbs;Texas;Davis, Wendy
results.title: In Texas, a Senator’s Stand Catches the Spotlight
results.abstract: Senator Wendy Davis was on her feet in pink running shoes filibustering an abortion bill for about 11 hours, drawing attention, fans, detractors and instant celebrity.

media.caption: State Senator Wendy Davis of Texas, was flanked by her father, left, and her two daughters while giving her victory speech on Nov. 6. Senator Davis, a Democrat, was first elected in 2008.
media.copyright: Robert W. Hart for The Texas Tribune

media.caption: State Senator Wendy Davis at her Harvard Law School graduation in 1993, with her daughter, Amber.
Ms. Davis in elementary school in the 1970s.

results.adx_keywords: Sleep
results.title: Steps for More, and Better, Sleep
results.abstract: In general, adults need at least seven hours of sleep, and being mindful of diet and exercise during the hours leading up to bedtime can help ensure a restful night.

results.adx_keywords: Snowden, Edward J;Hong Kong;Surveillance of Citizens by Government;Classified Information and State Secrets;Ho, Albert;National Security Agency
results.title: Hasty Exit Started With Pizza Inside a Hong Kong Hideout
results.abstract: During a meeting last week, Edward J. Snowden was deeply dismayed to learn that he could spend years in prison without a computer.

media.caption: Albert Ho, one of Edward J. Snowden’s lawyers, at a rally on June 15. The Hong Kong government was said to not trust Mr. Ho, a longtime campaigner for full democracy there.
A letter Edward J. Snowden signed on June 10 to retain Albert Ho and his firm's legal services in Hong Kong.

results.adx_keywords: Layoffs and Job Reductions; legal profession; Weil Gotshal & Manges; Legal Profession
results.title: Mass Layoffs at a Top-Flight Law Firm
results.abstract: The prestigious law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges is laying off a large number of lawyers and support staff, as well as reducing the pay of some partners, a move that underscores the difficulties facing the legal profession.

media.caption: Two former employees of Weil, Gotshal & Manges leaving the General Motors building in New York City after layoffs were announced on Monday.
media.copyright: Robert Caplin for The New York Times

media.caption: Outside Dewey & LeBoeuf in 2012. Some of its problems stemmed from the same trends facing successful firms like Weil.

results.title: Paula Deen Loses Major Endorsement Deal
results.abstract: Smithfield Foods, whose hams and other products Ms. Deen has endorsed since 2006, severed its relationship with her Monday.

media.caption: Paula Deen in 2010. Smithfield Foods, whose hams and other products Ms. Deen has endorsed since 2006, severed its relationship with her Monday. The world’s largest pork producer has been the flagship in her collection of at least 17 licensing and endorsement partnerships.
